The molecular weights of COMP3-Wt and -Mu peptides were measured by sedimentation equilibrium in a model E analytical ultracentrifuge. The solutions showed monodisperse species with molecular masses of 31,260 ± 170 Da for COMP3-Wt and 30,780 ± 100 Da COMP3-Mu (data not shown). The partial specific volume was calculated from the amino acid composition and found to be 0.678 cm3/g (36.Perkins S.J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1986; 157: 169-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (546) Google Scholar), and the degree of hydration was estimated to be 0.3 g/g. A comparison of the measured molecular weights with the molecular mass determined from the amino acid sequence (28,632 Da) indicates that the COMP3 peptides have little or no post-translational modifications (such as glycosylation). The slightly higher molecular weight of the COMP3-Wt peptides could be a reflection of more bound calcium (see below). The COMP3 peptides were analyzed for shape by centrifugation in 5–20% sucrose gradients in the presence and absence of calcium (Fig.5). Sedimentation coefficientss 20,w in the absence of calcium were 2.5 ± 0.1 S and 2.7 ± 0.1 S for the wild-type and mutant peptide, respectively. In the presence of calcium the sedimentation coefficient of the wild-type peptide changed to 2.8 ± 0.1 S, whereas the mutant peptide showed no change ins 20,w value. The increase ins 20,w of 2.5 to 2.8 for COMP3-Wt peptides indicates a significant change in the frictional ratio upon binding of calcium. This would be consistent with an earlier study of thrombospondin 1 that demonstrated an elongation of the subunit “arms” in the presence of EDTA (37.Lawler J. Derick L.H. Connolly J.E. Chen J.H. Chao F.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 3762-3772Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Using the determined sedimentation coefficient and molecular weight of COMP3-Wt and assuming the degree of hydration is 0.3 ml/g, the frictional ratio is 1.38 in the presence of calcium. This frictional ratio indicates that the hydrodynamic dimensions of the wild-type COMP3 peptide are 15.0 × 2.1 nm for a prolate ellipsoid or 13.4 × 1.8 nm for a rod. The measured length of the rotary shadowed image of the wild-type peptide, 14.2 nm, is consistent with these calculations. One important but speculative function of the type 3 domains in the thrombospondin family is to bind calcium. COMP3 peptide solutions were dialyzed against concentrations of calcium chloride ranging from 50 μm to 2 mm. A small amount of radiolabeled calcium was added for quantitative purposes. The free and protein-bound calcium concentrations were calculated for several experiments using protein concentrations that varied from 1.6 to 10.3 μm (Fig.6). The resulting plot indicated that the number of bound calcium molecules/molecule was much lower for the COMP3-Mu peptides (8 compared with 17 for COMP3-Wt). The Hill coefficient, a measure of the cooperativity of the binding curve, showed COMP3-Wt bound calcium in a more cooperative manner (3.74versus 1.57 for mutant COMP3). Also, the concentration at half saturation was 102 and 218 μm for wild-type and mutant peptide, respectively. Data presented here show the first measurable consequence that relates a mutation in COMP to a molecular mechanism involved in generating the PSACH phenotype. This consequence is an altered potential for mutant COMP peptides to bind calcium. The secondary and tertiary structures are quantitatively affected by the reduced calcium binding. Most mutations in COMP are clustered within the type 3 repeats in the skeletal dysplasias PSACH and MED; presumably other COMP mutations alter molecular structure in a similar way. The calcium binding data indicate a very complex scenario with a large number of potential binding sites and a highly cooperative mechanism for binding. The primary structure of the type 3 repeats conforms to the consensus sequence of the EF-hand motif, a common structure associated with calcium-binding proteins. Sites contain a stretch of amino acids represented by X, Y, Z, -X, -Y, -Z that provide coordinating oxygens for calcium-ligand interactions in a distinctive geometry. There are up to 13 such sites in the type 3 repeats that share homology with the EF-hand structure (16.Lawler J. Simons E.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 12098-12101Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) compared with 17 calcium ions shown to bind the COMP3 peptides here. The difference suggests that the COMP3 peptide forms a more complex structure than that represented by linear repeated sequences. The 17 potential binding sites determined for the COMP3 peptides are also higher than that previously calculated for TSP I where 35 ± 3 ions of calcium bound one trimeric TSP I molecule (15.Misenheimer T.M. Mosher D.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1729-1733Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), which is approximately 12 calcium ions per polypeptide. One of these 12 is assumed to be bound to the EGF-like repeat with the consensus sequence of a calcium binding EGF domain; the COMP domain structure predicts two calcium binding EGF repeats based on residues crucial for ligand binding (38.Handford P.A. Mayhew M. Baron M. Winship P.R. Campbell I.D. Brownlee G.G. Nature. 1991; 351: 164-167Crossref PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar). These differences may be because of slight variations in design of binding assays such as ligand concentration (15.Misenheimer T.M. Mosher D.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1729-1733Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar) or the small sequence differences between COMP and TSP 1. In addition to the 13 EF-hand-repeating motif structure, the type 3 repeats have also been organized into 8 repeating units called 3A and 3B with the asparatic acid and cysteine residues aligned (39.Lawler J. Hynes R.O. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 1635-1648Crossref PubMed Scopus (390) Google Scholar). This alignment suggests that the cysteine residues may form intradomain disulfide bonds, thus stabilizing the eight repeated units. However, the disulfide bonds have not been established and it is difficult to see how more than eight calcium ions would bind with this domain structure. The structural organization of the type 3 repeats is commonly viewed as a series of separately folded motifs along the polypeptide chain, although no structural data have been presented to support or dispute this presumption. The highly cooperative calcium binding data presented here strongly suggest that these sequence repeats form a single protein domain. This is also supported by the sequence conservation within all five thrombospondin family members. If the peptide was composed of independently folded domains, one could expect more variations within these repeated sequences. Therefore we propose that the type 3 sequence repeats form a single protein domain: the TSP type 3 domain. It is interesting to note that the mutant peptide bound less than half the normal amount of calcium and yet theoretically only one potential binding site would be directly affected. This suggests that other factors are involved. Calcium binding to TSP I occurs by a cooperative mechanism suggesting that there is a conformational change upon an initial binding event that effects the conformation of other sites. Thus, the impact of an amino acid mutation at one calcium binding site could greatly alter binding at other sites. The reduced calcium binding in the mutant COMP peptide has significant biological relevance in view of the effect of COMP mutations on skeletal development. Following translation of a COMP polypeptide, the chains normally assemble into a mature pentameric COMP molecule and are trafficked through the Golgi and secreted. The sequestration of COMP by PSACH chondrocytes may potentially be the result of quality control mechanisms within the rER that retain incorrectly folded proteins. Unsecreted COMP would thus accumulate in the rER and possibly form aggregates that include COMP and other cartilage components such as aggrecan and type IX collagen. Both of these molecules have been shown to be retained intracellularly in PSACH chondrocytes (19.Maddox B.K. Keene D.R. Sakai L.Y. Charbonneau N.L. Morris N.P. Ridgway C.C. Boswell B.A. Sussman M.D. Horton W.A. Bächinger H.P. Hecht J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30993-30997Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar, 20.Stanescu V. Maroteaux P. Stanescu R. Eur. J. Pediatr. 1982; 138: 221-225Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). In another calcium binding molecule, fibrillin, calcium binding maintains the tertiary structure of two adjacent EGF-like domains (34.Downing A.K. Knott V. Werner J.M. Cardy C.M. Campbell I.D. Handford P.A. Cell. 1996; 85: 597-605Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (377) Google Scholar). The results suggested that the calcium bound at the interface between the domains fixes the domains in a linear orientation. It is important to note that there is a significant difference in the potential effect of loss of calcium binding in fibrillin compared with COMP. In contrast to the calcium bound to fibrillin, calcium binding to COMP occurs in a cooperative manner. Perhaps calcium stabilizes a particular structure in COMP that promotes proper folding, secretion, and matrix assembly. The thrombospondin family members contain three regions that have been shown to or have potential to bind divalent cations: the two calcium binding EGF-like repeats, the type 3 domain with some homology to other calcium binding molecules, and the C terminus that has been shown to bind zinc (18.Rosenberg K. Olsson H. Mörgelin M. Heinegard D. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 20397-20403Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar). Of these, the only ionic association with biological relevance is that of zinc binding, which permits interaction with collagens I and II at the C terminus. This interaction is enormously significant in that COMP is a component of tendon and cartilage, two tissues that are affected in PSACH by COMP mutations. From the data presented here that show altered conformation of COMP3 peptides with the Asp-446 → Asn mutation, we speculate that the native molecular structure is also affected. It is likely that the interaction with fibrillar collagens and potentially other extracellular matrix components may be disrupted. In conclusion, data presented here demonstrate a direct, specific, measurable effect of PSACH-associated COMP mutations on molecular properties. The mutation, Asp-446 → Asn, reduces the potential of the COMP3 peptide to bind calcium ions resulting in a highly altered conformation. The secondary and tertiary structure was disturbed. With these results, it is proposed that the pathogenesis of PSACH includes the profound alteration of the type 3 domain and possibly the overall molecular structure. Future studies will be required to understand how the altered structure causes storage of selected cartilage components. We acknowledge the excellent technical assistance of Jay E. Gambee, Bruce A. Boswell, Sara F. Tufa, and Virginia L. Scott. In addition, we thank Drs. Lynn Sakai and Dieter Reinhardt for resources and technical support. We also thank Dr. Jürgen Engel for advice and helpful discussions.

Collagen XI is a heterotrimeric molecule found predominantly in heterotypic cartilage fibrils, where it is involved in the regulation of fibrillogenesis. This function is thought to involve the complex N-terminal domain. The goal of this current study was to examine its structural organization to further elucidate the regulatory mechanism. The amino-propeptide (α1-Npp) alone or with isoforms of the variable region were recombinantly expressed and purified by affinity and molecular sieve chromatography. Cys-1–Cys-4 and Cys-2–Cys-3 disulfide bonds were detected by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. This pattern is identical to the homologous α2-Npp, indicating that the recombinant proteins were folded correctly. Anomalous elution on molecular sieve chromatography suggested that the variable region was extended, which was confirmed using rotary shadowing; the α1-Npp formed a globular “head” and the variable region an extended “tail.” Circular dichroism spectra analysis determined that the α1-Npp comprised 33% β-sheet, whereas the variable region largely comprised non-periodic structure. Taken together, these results imply that the α1-Npp cannot be accommodated within the core of the fibril and that the variable region and/or minor helix facilitates its exclusion to the fibril surface. This provides further support for regulation of fibril diameter by steric hindrance or by interactions with other matrix components that affect fibrillogenesis. Collagen XI is a heterotrimeric molecule found predominantly in heterotypic cartilage fibrils, where it is involved in the regulation of fibrillogenesis. This function is thought to involve the complex N-terminal domain. The goal of this current study was to examine its structural organization to further elucidate the regulatory mechanism. The amino-propeptide (α1-Npp) alone or with isoforms of the variable region were recombinantly expressed and purified by affinity and molecular sieve chromatography. Cys-1–Cys-4 and Cys-2–Cys-3 disulfide bonds were detected by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. This pattern is identical to the homologous α2-Npp, indicating that the recombinant proteins were folded correctly. Anomalous elution on molecular sieve chromatography suggested that the variable region was extended, which was confirmed using rotary shadowing; the α1-Npp formed a globular “head” and the variable region an extended “tail.” Circular dichroism spectra analysis determined that the α1-Npp comprised 33% β-sheet, whereas the variable region largely comprised non-periodic structure. Taken together, these results imply that the α1-Npp cannot be accommodated within the core of the fibril and that the variable region and/or minor helix facilitates its exclusion to the fibril surface. This provides further support for regulation of fibril diameter by steric hindrance or by interactions with other matrix components that affect fibrillogenesis. N-terminal domain (refers to the N-propeptide plus peptides of the variable region) proline-arginine-rich protein N-propeptide domain of α2(XI) chain N-propeptide domain of α1(XI) chain (previously known as PARP-like domain of α1(XI) chain or α1-PARP domain) N-terminal, heparin binding domain of thrombospondin collagen molecules that retain their N-propeptides polymerase chain reaction polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium high performance liquid chromatography liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry Collagen XI is a component of fibrils both in cartilage and a wide variety of non-cartilaginous tissues, including brain, muscle, tendon, heart valve, skin, calvaria, and endochondral bone (1.Mendler M. Eich-Bender S.G. Vaughan L. Winterhalter K.H. Bruckner P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 191-197Crossref PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar, 2.Nah H.D. Barembaum M. Upholt W.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22581-22586Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In cartilage it assembles with collagens II and IX to produce an extensive network of thin, heterotypic collagen fibrils (15–25 nm in diameter; Ref. 1.Mendler M. Eich-Bender S.G. Vaughan L. Winterhalter K.H. Bruckner P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 191-197Crossref PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar) in which the other extracellular matrix components are embedded. The major triple helix of collagen XI is not accessible to antibodies unless the fibrils are disrupted, which led to the model that it is located in the interior of the fibril (1.Mendler M. Eich-Bender S.G. Vaughan L. Winterhalter K.H. Bruckner P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 191-197Crossref PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar, 3.Petit B. Ronziere M.C. Hartmann D.J. Herbage D. Histochemistry. 1993; 100: 231-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). In non-cartilaginous tissues, collagen XI has been found to co-assemble with chains of the highly homologous type V collagen (4.Kleman J.P. Hartmann D.J. Ramirez F. van der Rest M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 210: 329-335Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 5.Mayne R. Brewton R.G. Mayne P.M. Baker J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 9381-9386Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Collagen XI is a heterotrimeric molecule consisting of α1, α2, and α3 collagen chains (6.Eyre D. Wu J.-J. Structure and Function of Collagen Types. Academic Press, Orlando, FL1987: 261-281Google Scholar). The α3(XI) chain is an overglycosylated form of the α1(II) collagen chain (7.Furuto D.K. Miller E.J. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1983; 226: 604-611Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar), whereas the α1(XI) and α2(XI) chains are distinct gene products (8.Fichard A. Kleman J.P. Ruggiero F. Matrix Biol. 1995; 14: 515-531Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). The α1(XI) and α2(XI) chains contain similar large, N-terminal domains (NTDs),1 comprising a “PARP” or “PARP-like” domain, a variable region, and a minor triple helix (Fig. 1 a; Refs. 9.Yoshioka H. Ramirez F. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 6423-6426Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and 10.Zhidkova N.I. Justice S.K. Mayne R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9486-9493Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The PARP (proline-arginine rich protein) domain was originally isolated as a distinct protein from bovine cartilage (11.Neame P.J. Young C.N. Treep J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20401-20408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) but was later demonstrated to be a fragment of the N terminus of the α2(XI) chain (12.Zhidkova N.I. Brewton R.G. Mayne R. FEBS Lett. 1993; 326: 25-28Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Recently, the proteolytic processing site of the α1(XI) chain has been identified (13.Moradi-Ameli M. Rousseau J.C. Kleman J.P. Champliaud M.F. Boutillon M.M. Bernillon J. Wallach J. Van der Rest M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1994; 221: 987-995Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 14.Moradi-Ameli M. de Chassey B. Farjanel J. van der Rest M. Matrix Biol. 1998; 17: 393-396Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar), and since nearly all of the domain is removed by this processing event, both the PARP-like and PARP domains are now termed the amino-propeptides (Npp). The Npp domains are structurally homologous to modules found in seven other collagen chains, as well as the glycoproteins laminin and thrombospondin (15.Moradi-Ameli M. Deleage G. Geourjon C. van der Rest M. Matrix Biol. 1994; 14: 233-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 16.Bork P. FEBS Lett. 1992; 307: 49-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Both the α1 and α2 chains contain a variable region that lies between the Npp and the minor helix, and alternative splicing of the mRNA within these variable domains generates considerable sequence diversity (10.Zhidkova N.I. Justice S.K. Mayne R. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9486-9493Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 17.Tsumaki N. Kimura T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 2372-2378Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 18.Oxford J.T. Doege K.J. Morris N.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9478-9485Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). During chondrocyte differentiation, splicing of the α2(XI) mRNA rapidly converges to expression of a single protein isoform that lacks all segments encoded by alternatively spliced exons (19.Sugimoto M. Kimura T. Tsumaki N. Matsui Y. Nakata K. Kawahata H. Yasui N. Kitamura Y. Nomura S. Ochi T. Cell Tissue Res. 1998; 292: 325-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Conversely, alternative splicing of the α1(XI) mRNA at two separate sites during the differentiation process results in divergence from a single species to a complex set of protein isoforms. Six possible isoforms are synthesized, which are named according to the peptide encoded by the exon: p6a, p6b, p8, p[6a+8], p[6b+8] and p0, an isoform that contains constitutively expressed regions only (Fig.1 a). 2The recombinant proteins, which include the α1-Npp domain in addition to variable region, are referred to as p8 or p[6a+8] to designate which of the alternatively expressed peptides were present. Alternative splicing leads to considerable structural complexity, since the p6a and p8 peptides are acidic while the p6b peptide is extremely basic (18.Oxford J.T. Doege K.J. Morris N.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9478-9485Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). Although collagen XI comprises a relatively small amount of the total collagen present in cartilage fibrils, its presence is essential for the regulated assembly, organization, and development of the cartilage. This is evidenced by studies on the autosomal recessive chondrodysplasia (Cho) mouse, where a frameshift in the α1(XI) gene leads to a functional knock out of the gene product (20.Li Y. Lacerda D.A. Warman M.L. Beier D.R. Yoshioka H. Ninomiya Y. Oxford J.T. Morris N.P. Andrikopoulos K. Ramirez F. Wardell B.B. Lifferth G.D. Teuscher C. Woodward S.R. Taylor B.A. Seegmiller R.E. Olsen B.R. Cell. 1995; 80: 423-430Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (301) Google Scholar). The cartilage of these mice is atypical in that the collagen fibrils are much thicker than normal (21.Seegmiller R. Fraser F.C. Sheldon H. J. Cell Biol. 1971; 48: 580-593Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar, 22.Seegmiller R.E. Myers R.A. Dorfman A. Horwitz A.L. Connect. Tissue Res. 1981; 9: 69-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar), an observation that is consistent with a regulatory role for type XI collagen in fibril assembly. It has been proposed that the mechanism by which this occurs is similar to that by which collagen V limits the diameter of type I/V fibrils in the cornea (23.Linsenmayer T.F. Gibney E. Igoe F. Gordon M.K. Fitch J.M. Fessler L.I. Birk D.E. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 1181-1189Crossref PubMed Scopus (247) Google Scholar, 24.Birk D.E. Fitch J.M. Babiarz J.P. Doane K.J. Linsenmayer T.F. J. Cell Sci. 1990; 95: 649-657Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Here, the NTD of type V collagen at the fibril surface inhibits further accretion of collagen I monomers by steric hindrance or by electrostatic mechanisms (25.Marchant J.K. Hahn R.A. Linsenmayer T.F. Birk D.E. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 135: 1415-1426Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). In accordance with this model, the NTD of type XI collagen would limit the diameter of heterotypic cartilage fibrils and this may rely in part on the shape and dimensions of the NTD. The goal of this study, therefore, was to examine the structure of the Npp alone or with the alternatively spliced peptides, p8 and p[6a+8] to further elucidate the regulatory mechanism. These two isoforms are representative of both the non-cartilage form and up to 30% of the α1(XI) in cartilage (26.Davies G.B. Oxford J.T. Hausafus L.C. Smoody B.F. Morris N.P. Dev. Dyn. 1998; 213: 12-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). DNA constructs that code for the p8 and p[6a+8] isoforms were generated by reverse transcription-PCR using RNA from an immortalized rat chondrosarcoma cell line as a template (27.Oxford J.T. Doege K.J. Horton Jr., W.E. Morris N.P. Exp. Cell Res. 1994; 213: 28-36Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). To amplify the sequence, the upstream primer used was 5′-ATT AGC TAG CTG CTC CAG TTG ATA TAC TG-3′, and the downstream primer was 5′-ATT ACT CGA GAC TAG TGA TGG TGA TGG TGA TGG GGT TCA ACT ACA GCA GGT TCC CC-3′ (Fig. 1). The upstream primer included a unique NheI site, while the downstream primer encoded six histidine codons in tandem, a stop codon, a SpeI site, and a uniqueXhoI site, at the 3′ end. These primers were based on published cDNA sequence of the rat α1(XI) NTD (18.Oxford J.T. Doege K.J. Morris N.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9478-9485Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). The sequences were amplified using the Advantage HF PCR kit (CLONTECH) with the following amplification conditions: an initial denaturation at 94 °C for 3 min, 30 cycles of denaturation (94 °C for 45 s), annealing (65 °C for 30 s), elongation (72 °C for 1 min), and a final elongation for 10 min at 72 °C. The PCR products were analyzed on a 2.5% Nusieve agarose gel (3:1; FMC Bioproducts) and were cloned into theNheI-XhoI-cut pCEP4 mammalian episomal expression vector (Invitrogen), which had been modified to include the signal peptide and 5′-untranslated region of the basement membrane protein BM40 (28.Mayer U. Zimmermann K. Mann K. Reinhardt D. Timpl R. Nischt R. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 227: 681-686Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). Secreted recombinant proteins retain four amino acids from this signal peptide at the N terminus. Positive clones were selected by ampicillin resistance in Escherichia coli and their identity verified by DNA sequencing. The plasmid was harvested and transfected into human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293 cells that express the EBNA-1 protein (Invitrogen) using Pfx-2 lipid (Invitrogen). Cells were grown in DMEM/F-12 containing 10% fetal calf serum and transformed cells were positively selected for by addition of hygromycin (400 μg/ml) and G418 (50 μg/ml). These cells were expanded for large scale culture in serum-free DMEM/F-12. Expression of recombinant protein was detected for up to 2 months, and medium was collected twice a week. Pooled media was clarified by centrifugation before proceeding with protein purification. The α1-Npp sequence was amplified with the upstream primer 5′-TAA CTA GCT CCA GTT GAT ATA CTG AAA GCT TTA GAT TTT-3′ (Fig.1), which included a unique NheI restriction site. The downstream primer was 5′-ATT AGG ATC CAC TAG TGA TGG TGA TGG TGA TGC TGA GCG GCC TTG GAT GTT AAG TCA CA-3′, which encoded six histidine residues, a stop codon, a SpeI site, and a uniqueBamHI site at the 3′ end. The α1-Npp sequence was amplified using the Advantage HF PCR kit (CLONTECH), cloned into the pET 11a expression vector (Stratagene), and the identity was verified by sequencing. Positive clones were selected and plasmid DNA was used to transform BL21(DE3)pLysS-competent cells, which express T7 polymerase (Invitrogen). These were grown in LB medium, and α1-Npp was purified from the inclusion bodies of these cells by solubilizing in 8m urea, 14 mm β-mercaptoethanol. The protein was refolded by rapid dilution in 20 mm sodium phosphate, pH 7. 8, containing 0.25 m NaCl and then dialyzed against chelating column start buffer (see below). Recombinant p8 and p[6a+8] proteins were precipitated from serum-free medium by 30% ammonium sulfate and resuspended in start buffer (1 m NaCl, 20 mm sodium phosphate, 2 m urea, pH 7.1) containing protease inhibitors (1 mm N-ethylmaleimide, 1 mm[4-(2-aminoethyl)-benzenesulfonyl fluoride]hydrochloride and 1 mm benzamidine). Insoluble material was pelleted by centrifugation (18,000 × g for 30 min) and the resultant supernatant filtered through a 0.8-μm filter. This was loaded onto a 5-ml HiTrap chelating affinity column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) charged with 0.2 m cobalt chloride and equilibrated in start buffer. The absorbance was monitored continuously at 280 nm, and the flow rate was 2 ml/min. Bound proteins were eluted by a step gradient to 0.25 m imidazole. Proteins in each fraction were analyzed by SDS-PAGE (7.5% gel, reducing conditions) and stained with Coomassie Blue. Fractions containing recombinant protein were pooled, concentrated to 1 ml by ultrafiltration (Centriprep, Amicon), and passed over a Superose 12 column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) equilibrated in 0.1 m NaCl, 20 mmsodium phosphate, 2 m urea, pH 7.2. The absorbance was monitored continuously at 280 nm, and the flow rate was 0.25 ml/min. Purified recombinant protein was then concentrated on a Centricon filter unit (Amicon). α2-Npp was extracted with guanidine HCl from bovine nasal cartilage and purified as described previously (11.Neame P.J. Young C.N. Treep J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20401-20408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Purified p8 and p[6a+8] recombinant proteins were digested with CnBr in 70% formic acid to isolate the N terminus containing the disulfide-bonded cysteines. After digestion the sample was subjected to reverse-phase HPLC (Vydac C18 column 218TP52), and the N-terminal peptide was identified by Edman sequencing (Routine 3.5 chemistry, ABI Sequencer). This peptide was digested with chymotrypsin (Roche Molecular Biochemicals) in 50 mm NH4OAc, pH 6.8 at 20 °C for 18 h, then purified by reverse-phase HPLC with the following conditions: solvent A, 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid/H2O; solvent B, 0.08% trifluoroacetic acid/acetonitrile; gradient, 0–1.6% B, 63–29.6% B, 95–60% B, 105–80% B, 105.1–1.6% B. Disulfide-bonded peptides were identified by Edman sequencing. One hundred pmol of α1-Npp protein was digested with 2 pmol of sequencing-grade trypsin (Promega, Madison, WI) for 4 h in 50 mm ammonium bicarbonate. 1 pmol of the peptide digest was pressure-loaded onto a 75-μm capillary HPLC column for on-line analysis by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) in an ion-trap mass spectrometer (LCQ, Finnigan, San Jose, CA) as described (29.Gygi S.P. Rist B. Gerber S.A. Turecek F. Gelb M.H. Aebersold R. Nat. Biotechnol. 1999; 17: 994-999Crossref PubMed Scopus (4350) Google Scholar). As peptides eluted from the column, their mass/charge ratios were measured in the mass spectrometer. A second stage of mass spectrometry was then performed automatically, where a selected peptide ion was fragmented to collect sequence information. Disulfide bonds are stable under the conditions used, and no bond breakage between cysteines occurred. A mass/charge ratio 1315.8, [M + 3H]3+ corresponding to a trio of disulfide-bonded peptides was encountered during the run. A tandem mass spectrum was automatically collected, which was used to determine the correct order of disulfide arrangement. This trio was the only peak not present in an identical run where the peptide digest was reduced with 10 mm dithiothreitol for 1 h at 37 °C. ScanProsite was used to identify potential N-glycosylation sites, while the NetOGlyc 2.0 prediction server was used to predict potential GalNAcO-glycosylation sites of α1(XI) NTD. To assess whether the recombinant p[6a+8] protein was glycosylated, a sample was dialyzed against 20 mm sodium phosphate, pH 7.2, and incubated overnight at 37 °C with either 0.5 units of N-glycosidase F alone or in combination with 0.25 milliunits ofO-glycosidase (Roche Molecular Biochemicals). Digested and undigested control samples were separated on a 7.5% SDS-PAGE gel and stained with Coomassie Blue. For analysis of protein shape, p[6a+8] recombinant protein was passed over a Superose 12 molecular sieve column. This was performed in both denaturing (8m urea, 14 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 0.1m NaCl, 0.1 m Tris-HCl, pH 7.1, 0.1% Triton X-100) and non-denaturing conditions (0.1 m NaCl, 0.1m Tris-HCl, pH 7.1). The absorbance was monitored continuously at 280 nm, and the flow rate was 0.25 ml/min. SDS-PAGE was used to analyze every second fraction of the denatured buffer run to determine the elution position of p[6a+8]. The elution position was compared with a set of known globular proteins (670 to 1.35 kDa (Bio-Rad); 67 to 13.7 kDa (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech)) resuspended in identical buffers and run immediately prior to each of the experimental runs. The purified isoforms (10 μg/ml) were dialyzed against 0.2 m ammonium bicarbonate, sprayed onto mica, and shadowed with platinum (30.Morris N.P. Keene D.R. Glanville R.W. Bentz H. Burgeson R.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 5638-5644Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The images were viewed by transmission electron microscopy. Measurements were estimated from photomicrographs using a calibrated eyepiece. Only molecules with defined, extended tails were measured. To make the measurements more accurate, the size of the platinum particles, measured from the background, was subtracted from this value. Statistical analysis was performed and a standard error of the mean calculated. Purified recombinant isoforms (0.5–1 mg/ml) were dialyzed extensively against 0.1 m sodium phosphate, pH 7.2. Each sample was analyzed in the far-UV range (260–180 nm) at 24 °C by CD spectroscopy on a Jasco J-500 spectropolarimeter interfaced to a computer, using a quartz cell with a path length of 100 μm. Spectra were smoothed, and buffer base lines were subtracted. The secondary structure was subsequently estimated using the variable selection method with an initial set of 33 basis spectra (31.Compton L.A. Mathews C.K. Johnson Jr., W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 13039-13043Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This method of analysis is thought to be advantageous in estimating the β-sheet content of a protein (32.Greenfield N.J. Anal. Biochem. 1996; 235: 1-10Crossref PubMed Scopus (564) Google Scholar). The concentration of each sample was determined in triplicate by amino acid analysis. Samples were gas-phase hydrolyzed using 300 μl of 6 nHCl, 2% phenol at 110 °C for 22 h, and the hydrolysates were analyzed on a Beckman 6300 amino acid analyzer using sodium citrate buffers. For determination of the structure of the variable region, the difference between the normalized spectra of the α1-Npp and the p[6a+8] was obtained using a calculation that accounted for the different number of amino acids present in each domain. The resultant spectrum of the variable domain was then solved. Osguthorpe D.J. Robson B. J. Mol. Biol. 1978; 120: 97-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (3418) Google Scholar), (b) Gor2, a modification of Gor1 (34.Gibrat J.F. Garnier J. Robson B. J. Mol. Biol. 1987; 198: 425-443Crossref PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar), (c) Gor 4, a further improved version of Gor1 (35.Garnier J. Gibrat J.F. Robson B. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 266: 540-553Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), (d) self-optimized method for protein secondary structure prediction (SOPM; Ref. 36.Geourjon C. Deleage G. Protein Eng. 1994; 7: 157-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar), (e) SOPMA, an improved version of SOPM (37.Geourjon C. Deleage G. Comput. Appl. These prediction programs can all be accessed at the EXPASY web server, where the default options, if any, for e.g. window lengths and similarity thresholds, were chosen. Not all these programs predicted the same secondary structure for each sequence, so the prediction was based on agreement of at least four out of the nine methods implemented. The α1-Npp domain alone or the complete p[6a+8] isoform (Fig.1 b) were expressed as recombinant proteins in prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, respectively, as sufficient quantities could not be purified from cartilage. Recombinant p[6a+8] was initially purified by chelating affinity chromatography utilizing the 6-histidine tag incorporated into the construct (Fig. 2 a). SDS-PAGE analysis and Western blotting with monoclonal antibodies directed against the 6-histidine tag indicated that the material in pool B contained the recombinant protein (results not shown). However, Coomassie Blue staining of the same material showed the presence of a high M r contaminating protein (Fig.2 c, lane 2). The fractions containing partially purified recombinant protein were pooled, concentrated and passed over a Superose 12 molecular sieve column (Fig. 2 b). SDS-PAGE analysis and Coomassie Blue staining of the peak fractions indicated that the high M r contaminating protein was successfully removed (Fig. 2 c, lane 3), leaving substantially pure recombinant p[6a+8] protein in the second peak (Fig. 2 c, lane 4). These fractions were pooled and the protein concentrated for use in structural analyses. Recombinant α1-Npp was purified in an identical manner and the purified product is shown (Fig. 2 c,lane 5). The typical yields of purified recombinant protein were 1 mg of p[6a+8]/4 liters of DMEM/F-12 medium or 1 mg of α1-Npp/liter of LB medium. The disulfide bonds formed by the recombinant p[6a+8] protein were analyzed by peptide mapping under non-reducing conditions. After digestion with cyanogen bromide and chymotrypsin, Edman sequence analysis of disulfide-linked peptides revealed that Cys-1 was linked to Cys-4 and that Cys-2 was linked to Cys-3 (Fig. 3 a). There remains a possibility that a small amount of protein was not folded correctly but as the protein migrated as a single species on SDS-PAGE and eluted as a single, symmetrical peak on molecular sieve chromatography, it is likely that most, if not all, of the protein was folded correctly. The proper disulfide bond pairing of the recombinant α1-Npp was confirmed by LC-MS/MS. Disulfide analysis by LC-MS/MS of a tryptic digest of α1-Npp resulted in the detection of the mass/charge ratio for a trio of predicted disulfide cross-linked peptides with two possible cross-linked conformations (Fig. 3 b). A tandem mass spectrum corresponding to this peptide revealed the correct disulfide order because disulfides did not break under the conditions employed and amino acid sequence could be verified across the S-S bonds. Only a single peak disappeared in a comparison between native and reduced tryptic digests, and no other masses corresponding to any other predicted disulfide-linked peptides were identified, suggesting that the conformation detected was the only one present in the recombinant protein. The disulfide bond pattern detected for both the eukaryotic and prokaryotic recombinant proteins was identical to that of the highly homologous α2-Npp domain isolated from cartilage (11.Neame P.J. Young C.N. Treep J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 20401-20408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), indicating that the recombinant proteins are likely to be correctly folded. ScanProsite was used to analyze N-glycosylation sites in α1-Npp and the variable region. The sequence -NISE- was identified as a potential site within the p8 peptide. To assess whether the recombinant p[6a+8] was glycosylated, a sample was digested with N-glycosidase F, separated by SDS-PAGE, and stained with Coomassie Blue. It was found that the N-glycosidase digested sample migrated slightly further on SDS-PAGE compared with undigested control samples (Fig.4). This was also true for recombinant p8 protein, and in both cases double digestion with N- andO-glycosidase did not further increase the rate of migration (results not shown). Moreover, during the amino acid sequence analysis performed to map the disulfide bonds, the asparagine residue of the amino acid sequence -NISE- was absent, consistent with anN-glycosylation at this site within the p8 peptide. Following the molecular sieve purification of the p[6a+8] isoform, standard globular proteins were passed over the column in identical buffer conditions. It was observed that, in non-denaturing buffer, the p[6a+8] eluted at a much greater apparent molecular mass (∼280 kDa) than its mass calculated from its amino acid sequence (Fig. 5 a). The elution of p[6a+8] as a single, sharp, symmetric and included peak in non-denaturing conditions was an indication that the greater apparent molecular mass was not due to multimer formation, but rather an asymmetric conformation. When chromatographed under denaturing conditions (8 m urea, 14 mmβ-mercaptoethanol, 0.1% Triton X-100; Fig. 5 b), the p[6a+8] eluted at a position corresponding to approximately 66 kDa, the same apparent molecular mass determined by SDS-PAGE. Moreover, the α1-Npp domain eluted at a position corresponding to its molecular mass in non-denaturing conditions (results not shown), suggesting that asymmetry resides in the variable region. The indication of an asymmetric conformation of p[6a+8] was investigated further by use of rotary shadowing and electron microscopy. Rotary-shadowed images of both the recombinant α1-Npp and the α2-Npp domain showed a homogeneous population of small round particles, indicating formation of a compact, globular domain (Fig. 6, a andb). This observation is similar to the rotary shadowing images of the NC11 domain, a homologous domain found in type XVI collagen (42.Tillet E. Mann K. Nischt R. Pan T.C. Chu M.L. Timpl R. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 228: 160-168Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). Conversely, the p[6a+8] isoform, which contains variable region in addition to the Npp domain, displayed two distinct foldin

The reversible acetylation of histones is associated with structural alterations in the chromatin fiber that affect various DNA-related activities. Here we show that the histone acetyltransferase p300 specifically acetylates HMG-14, a nonhistone structural protein that binds to nucleosomes and reduces the compactness of the chromatin fiber. We identify 7 major acetylation sites, 6 of which are novel and have not been known to be acetylated in either HMG-14 or the closely related HMG-17 protein. All the acetylation sites involve evolutionarily conserved residues: 3 within the HMG-14/-17 nucleosomal binding domain and 4 in or near the bipartite nuclear localization domains of the proteins. In tissue culture cells the acetylation pattern is indicative of a selective process in which a subfraction of HMG-14 is preferentially acetylated. We find that the nucleosomal binding domain is a major target for acetylation in vivo and that the specific acetylation of HMG-14 by p300 weakens its interaction with nucleosome cores. Our results suggest that p300 modulates the interaction of HMG-14 with nucleosomes. Thus, p300 may affect chromatin-related activities not only by modifying histones or transcription factors but also by targeting structural nonhistone proteins. Nature. 1998; 392: 831-835Crossref PubMed Scopus (362) Google Scholar). It is generally accepted that the acetylation of specific lysine residues in the histone tails leads to chromatin decompaction (10.Ausio J. Dong F. van Holde K.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 206: 451-463Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar, 11.Fletcher T.M. Hansen J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 25359-25462Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar), thereby reducing the repressive effect of chromatin on transcription and replication as well as other DNA-related activities. However, it is also possible that histone acetylation affects the interaction of specific nucleosomes with regulatory factors (1.Hansen J. Tse C. Wolffe A. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 17637-17641Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar) or with the nuclear matrix (2.Davie J.R. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1998; 8: 173-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar) and that specific acetylation marks discrete functional states of the chromatin (12.Braunstein M. Sobel R.E. Allis C.D. Turner B.M. Broach J.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 4249-4356Crossref Scopus (327) Google Scholar, 13.ONeill L.P. Turner B.M. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 3946-3957Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). In this respect, it is significant that the reversible acetylation of histones is targeted and specific; that is, discrete lysine residues are targeted by specific acetyltransferases (2.Davie J.R. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1998; 8: 173-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). Most of the studies on the function and specificity of the acetylation activity of transcription coactivators focused on the reversible acetylation of the N termini of histone tails. However, these transcription coactivators also acetylate nonhistone proteins (14.Kouzarides T. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1999; 9: 40-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (586) Google Scholar), a modification that has significant functional consequences. Thus, the binding of p53 to its target DNA sequence is facilitated by the residue-specific acetylation by PCAF1 and p300 (15.Sakaguchi K. Herrera J.E. Saito S. Miki T. Bustin M. Vassilev A. Anderson C.W. Appella E. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 2831-2841Crossref PubMed Scopus (1015) Google Scholar, 16.Gu W. Roeder R.G. Cell. 1997; 90: 595-606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2154) Google Scholar, 17.Liu L. Scolnick D.M. Trievel R.C. Zhang H.B. Marmorstein R. Halazonetis T.D. Berger S.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 1202-1209Crossref PubMed Scopus (648) Google Scholar), and the DNA binding of the transcription factors GATA-1 (18.Boyes J. Byfield P. Nakatani Y. Ogryzko V. Nature. 1998; 396: 594-598Crossref PubMed Scopus (633) Google Scholar) and erythroid Krüppel-like factor (19.Zhang W. Bieker J.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 9855-9860Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar) is affected by a p300-mediated acetylation. The acetylation of HMG-I by CBP, but not by PCAF, leads to interferon-β enhanceosome disassembly and turns off interferon-β gene expression (20.Munshi N. Merika M. Yie J. Senger K. Chen G. Thanos D. Mol. Cell. 1998; 2: 457-467Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar). PCAF also specifically acetylates lysine 2 in the nonhistone HMG-17, a modification that alters the interaction of the protein with the nucleosome core. Interestingly, PCAF does not acetylate the closely related protein HMG-14 (21.Herrera J. Sakaguchi K. Bergel M. Trieschmann L. Nakatani Y. Bustin M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 3466-3473Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). Chromosomal proteins HMG-14 and HMG-17 are the only nuclear proteins known to specifically bind to the 146-base pair nucleosome core particle (22.Bustin M. Reeves R. Cohn W.E. Moldave K. Progress in Nucleic Acid Research and Molecular Biology. 54. Academic Press, Inc., San Diego, CA1996: 35-100Google Scholar). Although these proteins, as well as other members of the HMG class, are relatively abundant and ubiquitously found in all higher eukaryotes, very few studies examined their pattern of acetylation. In duck erythrocytes, Allfrey and co-workers (23.Sterner R. Vidali G. Allfrey V.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 8892-8895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) identify two acetylation sites, at positions 2 and 4, in both HMG-14 and HMG-17 and an additional acetylation site at position 10, in HMG-17 (23.Sterner R. Vidali G. Allfrey V.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 8892-8895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Our finding that PCAF specifically acetylates Lys 2 in HMG-17 but does not acetylate the closely related HMG-14 (21.Herrera J. Sakaguchi K. Bergel M. Trieschmann L. Nakatani Y. Bustin M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 3466-3473Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) suggests that in a fashion analogous to the acetylation of the histone tails, the acetylation of HMG-14/-17 is targeted and specific; that is, specific lysine residues are differentially acetylated by specific acetylases. We therefore searched for additional acetylases that modify these proteins in a biologically meaningful way and studied the ability of the transcription co-activator p300, which is a potent histone acetylase (24.Ogryzko V.V. Sciltz R.L. Russanova V. Howard B.H. Nakatani Y. Cell. 1996; 87: 953-959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2373) Google Scholar), to acetylate HMG-14/-17. Here we report that p300 specifically acetylates both HMG-14 and HMG-17 at multiple sites. All of the acetylation sites are at lysine residues that are conserved among all the members of the HMG-14/-17 protein family. Most of the acetylation sites identified have not been previously reported and represent novel sites for this type of modification. The most prominent acetylation sites are located in the nucleosomal binding domain of the protein, suggesting that acetylation may alter the interaction of HMG-14 with chromatin. By equilibrium dialysis we demonstrate that indeed, the p300-mediated acetylation reduces the affinity of HMG-14 to nucleosomes. Additional prominent acetylation sites are located in the bipartite nuclear localization signal of the protein (25.Hock R. Scheer U. Bustin M. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 143: 1427-1436Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar), raising the possibility that these modifications may also affect the intranuclear distribution of HMG-14/-17 proteins. Taken together, these results suggest that the p300 acetylation may affect the cellular function of HMG-14/-17 proteins. Recombinant human p300 containing the Flag tag (Eastman Kodak Co.) Cytochrome c and acetyl-CoA were obtained from Sigma, [1-14C]acetyl-CoA (55 mCi/mmol) was obtained from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, and [3H]acetyl-CoA (26 Ci/mmol) was obtained from Moravek Inc. Assays were performed in buffer A (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 10% glycerol (v/v), 1 mm dithiotheitol, 0.1 mmEDTA, 10 mm butyric acid) (28.Brownell J.E. Allis C.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1995; 92: 6364-6368Crossref PubMed Scopus (238) Google Scholar) or in 2× TBE (89 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.3, 89 mm sodium borate, 1 mm EDTA), 1 mm dithiotheitol buffer at protein substrate concentrations of 0.1 to 0.25 mg/ml. The concentration of either [3H]acetyl-CoA or [1-14C]acetyl-CoA was 18 μm. The concentration of recombinant p300 in the reaction mixture was 8 ng/μl. The standard assay was performed at 37 °C for 20 min and initiated by adding the protein substrate to a mixture containing the acetyltransferase and acetyl-CoA in the relevant buffer. HMG-14 was acetylated by p300 using 120 μm nonradioactive sodium acetyl-CoA (Sigma), as described above. To increase the yield of acetylated protein, the reaction time was extended to 3 h, with addition of fresh enzyme and 120 μm of acetyl-CoA every hour. The reaction mixtures were fractionated by reverse phase HPLC on an Aquapore (7 μm) butyl column (250 × 4.6 mm) using a 0–30% acetonitrile, 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid gradient at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. HMG-14 was eluted from the column at approximately 20% acetonitrile. The HMG-14 peak was collected and digested with either Asp-N (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), Arg-C (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), or human plasma kallikrein (Sigma) as recommended by the manufacturer. The digested HMG-14 was run on the Beckman System Gold HPLC using an Upchurch α-chrom C18 column (150 × 2.1 mm) and eluted with a linear gradient of 0–60% acetonitrile, 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (flow rate of 200 μl/min.). Peptides were sequenced on a Beckman LF3000G protein sequencer equipped with System Gold on-line phenylthiohydantoin analysis. HMG-14 was acetylated in 2× TBE, 1 mm dithiotheitol containing radioactively labeled acetyl-CoA for 3 h at 37 °C (as described above). Fresh p300 and acetyl-CoA were added after each hour. After acetylation, p300 was heat-inactivated by incubating the reaction mixture at 95 °C for 5 min. The dialysis was performed using Teflon equilibrium chambers (Sialomed Inc.) and 100-kDa cutoff membranes as described by Herreraet al. (21.Herrera J. Sakaguchi K. Bergel M. Trieschmann L. Nakatani Y. Bustin M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 3466-3473Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). For mass spectral analysis we employed either the PerSeptive Biosystems Voyager™ DE matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time of flight spectrometer using the delayed extraction protocol or surface-enhanced lazer desorption ionization PBS, (Ciphergen Biosystems, Inc.). In the surface-enhanced lazer desorption ionization PBS analysis, 1–2 μl of an HPLC fraction (lyophilized and redissolved in water) were spotted on a hydrophobic chip, and 1 μl of matrix (saturated sinapinic acid in 50% acetonitrile, 50% HPLC grade water and 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid) was added. Logarithmically growing (around 0.5 × 106cells/ml) or stationary phase (1.4–1.6 × 106cells/ml) HeLa S3 cells grown in suspension were concentrated 25-fold by centrifugation. The concentrated cells were incubated in 37 °C while shaking gently for 10 min with 200 μg/ml cycloheximide (Sigma) and for 1 additional h in the presence of 10 μmtrichostatin A (WAKO) and 0.25 mCi/ml [3H]acetate (20 Ci/mmol, Moravek). The cells were harvested by centrifugation, and the HMGs were extracted with 5% perchloric acid. The remaining pellets were extracted with 0.25 m sulfuric acid to obtain the core histones, which were used as controls. The HMGs from the homogenate were precipitated overnight at −20 °C with 6 volumes of acetone, 0.3 m HCl. The core histones were precipitated with 6 volumes of acetone. The precipitated proteins were washed with 95% acetone, air-dried, and dissolved in water. To determine the protein specific activity the proteins were run on 15% SDS-PAGE, and their amounts were estimated by staining the gel with Coomassie Blue. The bands were excised, digested at 70 °C overnight with 30% hydrogen peroxide, and the [3H]acetate incorporation into each band was determined by scintillation counting. Rabbit anti-p300 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology), which does not cross-react with CBP, was used to specifically immunoprecipitate p300 from HeLa nuclear extracts (Upstate Biotechnology). Various amounts of the anti-p300 antibody (see “Results”) were incubated overnight at 4 °C in 2× TBE with 20 μg of total protein from the HeLa nuclear extract. As controls, higher concentrations of rabbit nonimmune IgG were used in parallel. 13 μl of packed agarose-protein A (Life Technologies, Inc.) were washed twice with 2× TBE and added to every immunoprecipitation reaction. The mixtures were incubated at 4 °C (with rotation) for 2–3 h, and the beads were pelleted by centrifugation and washed 3 times in 2× TBE. Both the washed beads and the depleted supernatants were made 1 mm in dithiotheitol in a total volume of 13 μl of 2× TBE buffer and brought to a final concentration of 80 μm [14C]acetyl-CoA. 0.5 μg of HMG-14 was added to each reaction tube and acetylated for 30 min in 37 °C. The reaction was stopped by adding an equal volume of SDS-gel sample buffer, and then boiling for 5 min. The level of acetylation was quantified by running the products on 15% SDS-PAGE as described above. To examine whether the two closely related nonhistone proteins HMG-14 and HMG-17 are specifically acetylated by p300 we tested the ability of the enzyme to incorporate radioactive acetate into these proteins. Phosphorimage analysis of proteins separated on SDS-gels (Fig.1 B, see Fig. 1 A for corresponding Coomassie) demonstrates that the recombinant human p300 efficiently acetylates both HMG-14 and HMG-17. The acetylation is specific since lysozyme and cytochrome c, which also have a high content of lysines, were not acetylated by the enzyme (lanes 1 and 2 in Fig. 1, A and B). Nucleosomal histones served as positive controls. The labeling was enzyme-dependent since reaction mixtures containing [14C]acetyl-CoA but lacking enzyme failed to incorporate acetate into the HMG proteins (not shown). We conclude therefore that both HMG-14 and HMG-17 are specifically acetylated by p300. To assess the number of acetylation sites in HMG-14 and HMG-17, the acetylated proteins were run on Triton-acid-urea polyacrylamide gels under conditions known to resolve acetylated species of core histones. Both Coomassie Blue staining (Fig. 1 C) and autoradiographic analysis (Fig. 1 D) resolved five molecular species in both HMG-14 and HMG-17. As expected, the number of molecular species and the relative intensities of the bands correlated with the substrate to enzyme ratios in the reaction mixture (compare lanes 1 with2 and 3 with 4). Quantitative analysis, obtained by densitometric scanning and scintillation counting of each band, clearly indicated that the relative specific activity of the bands correlates with their electrophoretic mobility. The bands marked 0 (Fig. 1 D) were not radioactive. The bands marked as 1 contained about 8 × 104cpm. For comparative purposes the specific activity of these bands was taken to be 1.0. For HMG-14, the relative specific activity of the bands marked 2, 3, and 4 was 1.6, 2.1, and 4.4, respectively. For HMG-17, the relative specific activity of bands 2 and 3 was 2.2 and 3.1, respectively. The specific activity of the bands marked 4 and 5 was higher, but due to the low protein stain, could not be reliably measured. Analysis of the acetylation reactions of HMG-14 by reverse phase HPLC using C4 Aquapore columns also indicated that p300 acetylates this protein at multiple sites in a substrate-dependent manner. An increase in the acetyl-CoA concentration increased the number of peaks and shifted the elution profile toward longer retention time. At saturating concentrations of acetyl-CoA (120 μm), at least five peaks could be resolved (Fig. 1 E). We conclude therefore that p300 acetylates HMG-14 (and HMG-17) at multiple sites. The only reported acetylation sites in HMG-14 are the lysine residues at positions 2 and 4 (23.Sterner R. Vidali G. Allfrey V.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 8892-8895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Our findings that HMG-14 is efficiently acetylated by p300 at multiple sites indicated the presence of additional acetylation sites in the protein. To identify the protein regions containing the acetylated residues, we used peptides corresponding to various regions of HMG-14 to compete for the acetylation of the intact protein. Peptides corresponding either to the N-terminal region or to the nucleosomal binding domain or spanning one of the nuclear localization signals efficiently inhibited the acetylation in a dose-dependent manner (Fig.2, A–C). Peptide 6, corresponding to the C-terminal region of the protein, was incapable of competing with HMG-14 in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting that this region does not contain a major acetylation site. The peptides themselves were poor substrates for acetylation (not shown), suggesting that the specificity of acetylation is not solely dependent on the peptide sequence in the vicinity of the target site (21.Herrera J. Sakaguchi K. Bergel M. Trieschmann L. Nakatani Y. Bustin M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 3466-3473Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). To identify the sites acetylated by p300 in the intact HMG-14 protein, we cleaved the acetylated protein with the specific proteases Asp-N, Arg-C, or kallikrein (Fig. 2 E). The peptides were fractionated by HPLC, and the purified peptides were sequenced on a Beckman sequencer. Using a synthetic peptide we unequivocally identified the retention time of ε-N-acetyllysine (Fig.2 D), thus enabling us to use nonradioactive acetyl-CoA to determined the ratio of ε-N-acetyllysine to lysine after each sequencing step and quantify the relative levels of acetylation of each of the lysines in HMG-14 (Fig. 2 E). Using this approach we find that there are seven major acetylation sites (more than 25% of the lysines at that position modified): one in the N-terminal region at Lys-2, which is part of nuclear localization signal (25.Hock R. Scheer U. Bustin M. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 143: 1427-1436Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar), three in the nucleosomal binding domain at lysines 30, 37, and 41, and three at or near the second element of the bipartite nuclear localization signals of the protein, at lysines 54, 58, and 60. In addition, we identify 6 minor acetylation sites: 5 of them at positions 13, 17, 26, 47, and 52 in the N-terminal half of the protein, and 1 of them at position 81 in the C-terminal region. Additional studies with truncation mutants were in full agreement with these findings. The specific activity of truncation mutants lacking either the first 4 amino acids or the last 26 amino acids was very similar to that of the intact protein (not shown). With the exception of Lys-2, all of these acetylation sites are novel sites that were not previously known to be acetylated in either HMG-14 or in HMG-17. The acetylation is specific to the identified residues since some of the lysine residues in the protein were not acetylated at all. To test whether cellular p300 actually acetylates HMG-14, we specifically immunoprecipitated p300 from HeLa nuclear extracts with previously characterized antibodies and tested the ability of both the immunoprecipitates and the depleted supernatants to acetylate recombinant HMG-14. As demonstrated in Fig.3, the immunoprecipitates efficiently acetylated HMG-14. The specific activity of HMG-14 acetylated by the material immunoprecipitated with 1 μg of specific antibodies was 4.5-fold higher than that immunoprecipitated with 1 μg of nonspecific, control IgG (compare lanes 1 and 4in Fig. 3, A and B). A 2-fold increase in the amount of anti p300 antibodies did not significantly change the activity of the immunoprecipitate, suggesting that the antibodies were sufficient to immunodeplete most of the p300 acetylase activity in the HeLa extracts. Conversely, the supernatant from the p300-depleted extracts lost more than 50% of the acetylase activity as compared with the supernatants of the extracts treated with twice the amount of control antibodies (compare lane 5 with lane 8). Although the activity of p300 in HeLa nuclear extracts is not necessarily proportional to that in living cells, our results suggest that p300 is an active, major HMG-14 acetyltransferase in vivo. To examine the in vivo pattern of HMG-14 acetylation, we labeled both logarithmically growing and stationary phase HeLa S3 cells with [3H]acetate in the presence of the protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide and in either the presence or absence of the histone deacetylase inhibitors Trichostatin A or sodium butyrate. In logarithmically growing cells, in the absence of histone deacetylase inhibitors, the specific activity of HMG-14 was 75-fold lower than that of histone H3. The deacetylase inhibitors Trichostatin A and sodium butyrate increased the specific activity of histone H3 3.5-fold but did not affect the specific activity of HMG-14, suggesting that distinct type of deacetylases are acting on HMG-14. Indeed a HeLa nuclear extract deacetylated radioactively labeled H4, but not labeled HMG-14, in a Trichostatin A-sensitive manner (not shown). In stationary phase cells the specific activity of HMG-14 was 5.5 higher, whereas that of histone H3 was 2-fold lower than the specific activities of the proteins extracted from logarithmically growing cells, and the specific activity of HMG-14 was only 6-fold lower than that of histone H3. From these experiments we conclude that HMG-14 is acetylated in vivo and that the in vivo levels of HMG-14 acetylation may correlate with the metabolic state of the cell. Next, we isolated the HMG fraction from radioactively labeled stationary phase cells and purified the various HMG proteins on HPLC. We noted two peaks with an elution time corresponding to free and acetylated HMG-14 (Fig. 4 A). Examination by SDS-PAGE (not shown) indicated that most of the cellular HMG-14 was present in the major peak, eluting at a retention time of 9.4 min. The smaller peak eluting at 9.8 min also contained HMG-14 as determined by SDS electrophoresis, mass spectra, and sequence analysis (not shown). The specific activity of the HMG-14 in this late-eluting peak was 33 times higher than that of the HMG-14 eluting in the major peak. Thus, the HPLC retention time of the in vivoacetylated HMG-14 is longer than that of nonacetylated HMG-14, an observation that is in agreement with the in vitro studies on HMG-14 acetylation (Fig. 1). This highly acetylated fraction composes approximately 3% of total cellular HMG-14. We note that this level is higher than that of other acetylated nonhistones such as HMG-I(Y) (20.Munshi N. Merika M. Yie J. Senger K. Chen G. Thanos D. Mol. Cell. 1998; 2: 457-467Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar) and p53 (15.Sakaguchi K. Herrera J.E. Saito S. Miki T. Bustin M. Vassilev A. Anderson C.W. Appella E. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 2831-2841Crossref PubMed Scopus (1015) Google Scholar, 16.Gu W. Roeder R.G. Cell. 1997; 90: 595-606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (2154) Google Scholar, 17.Liu L. Scolnick D.M. Trievel R.C. Zhang H.B. Marmorstein R. Halazonetis T.D. Berger S.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 1202-1209Crossref PubMed Scopus (648) Google Scholar), where the cellular levels of acetylation were too low to be quantified. The results suggest that in HeLa cells the HMG-14 acetylation pattern is not random and does not target all the potential acetylation sites in all of the HMG-14 molecules. The acetylation pattern is indicative of a selective process in which a subfraction of the HMG-14 is highly acetylated, whereas most of the cellular HMG remains unacetylated. Since the in vitro analysis revealed novel acetylation sites located in the central region of HMG-14, we tested whether this HMG-14 region is also acetylated in vivo.3H-Labeled HMG-14 was isolated from stationary phase HeLa cells by a 5% PCA extraction followed by two cycles of reverse phase HPLC and proteolysis with kallikrein. The resulting peptides were separated on Tris-Tricine polyacrylamide gels, and the specific activity of each of the peptides was determined. The peptides were identified by calibration experiments in which recombinant HMG-14 protein was proteolized with kallikrein, and the digestion products were separated both on Tris-Tricine gels (Fig. 4 B) and on reverse phase HPLC (not shown). The peptides that were run on the gel were transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride filters and subjected to N-terminal sequencing. The HPLC fractions were also subjected to N-terminal sequencing and to mass spectroscopy analysis. As already demonstrated (Fig. 2 E), kallikrein digests HMG-14 at two major sites: the C terminus of residue 19 and the C terminus of residue 59. Thus, the partial digestion products identified on the gel (Fig.4 B) are the intact protein and the fragments spanning residues 20–99, 20–59, and 1–19. From the data summarized in Fig. 4 C it is apparent that thein vivo pattern of HMG-14 acetylation is in full agreement with the p300-mediated in vitro acetylation pattern obtained by sequence analysis (Fig. 2 E). Thus, the specific activity of the peptide-spanning amino acids 20–59 is very similar to that of either the entire protein or to a longer peptide spanning residues 20–99. These results clearly indicate that the central region of HMG-14, which contains the nucleosomal binding domain of the protein, is acetylated in vivo. The high level of acetylation in the nucleosomal binding domain of the protein raises the possibility that the p300-mediated acetylation may modulate the interaction of HMG-14 with nucleosomes. Since p300 acetylates HMG-14 at multiple sites, it is not possible to obtain a homogeneous fully acetylated HMG species suitable for the determination of an affinity constant by mobility shift assays. We therefore performed equilibrium dialysis experiments to examine the effect of the p300-mediated acetylation on the binding of HMG-14 to nucleosome core particles. In this test the acetylated and nonacetylated HMG-14 species compete for binding to nucleosome cores under identical conditions. We first acetylated HMG-14 with [14C]acetyl-CoA and then heat-inactivated the p300. We already demonstrated that the heat treatment does not affe

SoulA© & Sanjayan suggested that about 50% of the total land area is needed for protecting global biodiversity ( Science , 27 March 1998, p. [2060][1]). Such a target for nature conservation doesn't have a chance in Africa without serious and long-lasting investment in economic development. Economic development is a condition sine qua non for ambitious nature conservation projects in Africa. Therefore, [ Musters et al. ][2] plead for local sustainable development projects, preferably in presently domesticated areas. Such projects do not focus on nature conservation while compensating for economic losses, nor do they try to maximize economic growth; instead they look for optimal solutions by carefully considering economic, social, and ecological side effects of potential developments.

The tumor suppressor protein p53 plays a central role in modulating the cellular responses to DNA damage. Several recent studies, undertaken with the whole genomic DNA or full-length gene segments, have shown that p53 is involved in nucleotide excision repair and it selectively influences the adduct removal from the non-transcribed strand in the genome. In this study, we have analyzed the damage induction at nucleotide resolution by ligase-mediated polymerase chain reaction and compared the repair of ultraviolet radiation-induced cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers within exon 8 of p53 gene in normal and Li-Fraumeni syndrome fibroblasts as well as in normal and human papillomavirus 16 E6 and E7 protein-expressing human mammary epithelial cells. The results demonstrate that (i) loss or disruption of p53 function decreases efficiency of DNA repair, by preferentially affecting the repair of non-transcribed strand and of intrinsically slow repair sites in transcribed strand; (ii) mutant p53 protein affects DNA repair, at least of non-transcribed strand, in a dominant negative manner; and (iii) pRb does not have an effect on the repair of DNA damage within transcribed or non-transcribed strand. The overall data suggest that p53 could regulate excision repair or related events through direct protein-protein interaction. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 23465-23468Crossref PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar, 6.Mullenders L.H. Mutat. Res. DNA Repair. 1998; 409: 59-64Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). NER removes many types of DNA lesions including cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers (CPDs) by global genomic repair (GGR) and transcription-coupled repair (TCR) (5.Wood R.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 23465-23468Crossref PubMed Scopus (378) Google Scholar, 6.Mullenders L.H. Mutat. Res. DNA Repair. 1998; 409: 59-64Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar, 7.Drapkin R. Sancar A. It is now well established that NER along genome is heterogeneous, CPDs are more efficiently removed from transcriptionally active genes, and TCR is generally faster than GGR (2.Petit C. Sancar A. Biochimie. 1999; 81: 15-25Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 9.Tornaletti S. Hanawalt P.C. Biochimie. 1999; 81: 139-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar, 10.Frit P. Bergmann E. GGR acts on the elimination of lesions from non-transcribed strand (NTS) and transcriptionally inactive genes, whereas TCR removes lesions from DNA strand transcribed by RNA polymerase II. In mammalian cells, a variety of cellular responses following genotoxic exposure may contribute to prevent DNA lesions from interfering with essential cellular functions. Of those cellular responses, activation of p53 pathway is well studied and documented (11.Oren M. Rotter V. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 1999; 55: 9-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar, 12.Agarwal M.L. Taylor W.R. Chernov M.V. Chernova O.B. Stark G.R. J. Biol. It is believed that p53 activation signals the G1 arrest to delay the transit from G1 to S, thus preventing the effects of DNA lesions on vital cellular functions. Accumulating evidence indicates that p53 plays a role in DNA repair, especially in GGR (13.Wani M.A. Zhu Q.Z. El-mahdy M. Wani A.A. Carcinogenesis. 1999; 20: 765-772Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 14.Smith M.L. Chen I.-T. Zhan Q. O'Connor P.M. Fornace Jr., A.J. Oncogene. 1995; 10: 1053-1059PubMed Google Scholar, 18.Ford J.M. Baron E.L. Hanawalt P.C. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 599-603PubMed Google Scholar, 19.Prost S. Ford J.M. Taylor C. Doig J. Harrison D.J. J. Conceivably, p53 could be involved in NER by regulating its downstream genes, which are either related to or actively participate in NER. For example, Gadd45 and p21 waf1, which are among the many p53-regulated proteins, have been shown to interact with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (21.Smith M.L. Chen I.T. Zhan Q. Bae I. Chen C.-Y. Gilmer T.M. Kastan M.B. O'Connor P.M. Fornace Jr., A.J. Science. 1994; 266: 1376-1380Crossref PubMed Scopus (896) Google Scholar). Additionally, recent evidence has shown that p48, a UV-damaged DNA-binding protein is transcriptionally regulated by p53, linking p53 to NER (22.Hwang B.J. Ford J.M. Hanawalt P.C. Chu G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 424-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (505) Google Scholar). Besides transcriptional activation, p53 may also be directly involved in repair or repair-related processes. For example, in addition to demonstrated p53 binding to insertion/deletion mismatches (23.Lee S. Elenbass B. Levine A.J. Griffith J. Cell. 1995; 81: 1013-1020Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar), p53 has also been found to both physically and functionally interact with p62, XPD, and XPB, three components of basal transcription factor IIH (10.Frit P. Bergmann E. Egly J.-M. Biochimie. 1999; 81: 27-38Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar, 24.Wang X.W. Forrester K. Yeh H. Feitelson M.A. Gu J.-R. Harris C.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 2230-2234Crossref PubMed Scopus (635) Google Scholar). Despite a plethora of experimental data, the definitive role of p53 in NER and the mechanistic basis of its interaction with repair machinery has not been fully delineated in eukaryotic systems. Several observations, either supporting a pronounced effect of p53 for an efficient repair of NTS alone or its involvement also in the repair of transcribed strand (TS), have been put forth to identify the role of p53 in NER (13.Wani M.A. Zhu Q.Z. El-mahdy M. Wani A.A. Carcinogenesis. 1999; 20: 765-772Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 14.Smith M.L. Chen I.-T. Zhan Q. O'Connor P.M. Fornace Jr., A.J. Carcinogenesis. 1996; 17: 691-698Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). These observations are primarily based upon the assessment of an average of the repair events within an entire genome, a specific gene segment, or in some cases an episomally replicating plasmid within mammalian host cells. Thus, in the present study we performed the damage analysis at nucleotide resolution and systematically compared DNA repair of individual UV-induced CPD sites in normal, p53 mutant (p53-Mut), and p53 nullizygous (p53-Null) Li-Fraumeni syndrome (LFS) fibroblasts, as well as in normal, human papillomavirus (HPV) 16 E6 and E7 protein-expressing human mammary epithelial cells (HMEC). Our results show that, compared with the efficiency of TS repair, a significantly reduced rate of CPD removal was observable at all the dipyrimidine target sites of exon 8 NTS in both p53-Null and p53-Mut LFS cell lines. A close comparison of the extent of damage removal at 24 and 48 h after UV irradiation indicated that the repair of NTS was more severely affected in p53-Mut cells than in p53-Null cells. Relatively slight decrease in the initial rate of repair within TS, discernible at 24 h after treatment, was fully apparent at the inherently slow repair sites, e.g.codons 286 and 294 of p53 gene. This selective effect of p53 protein on the slow repair site of TS was much more clearly demonstrable at the same site in HPV 16 E6-expressing HMEC in which p53 is functionally inactivated by E6 protein. Like LFS cells, HPV 16 E6-expressing HMEC show a reduced rate of repair of CPDs in the NTS than in the TS. Both normal HMEC, having wild-type p53 and pRb proteins, and the isogenic HPV 16 E7-expressing HMEC, having wild-type p53 and compromised pRb protein expression, failed to show the deficiency of CPD repair in NTS as seen clearly due to the absence of p53 within human cells. Thus, pRb, another important cell cycle regulatory protein, does not seem to influence the NER process to a meaningful extent. Carcinogenesis. 1995; 16: 2029-2036Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). D. Anderson Cancer Center, Austin, TX). These fibroblast cells were grown in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum and antibiotics at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2. A. 1995; 92: 3687-3691Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). Denissenko M.F. Wani A.A. Carcinogenesis. 1995; 16: 2029-2036Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). The medium was removed, and cells were washed with prewarmed phosphate-buffered saline and irradiated with desired doses of UV (254-nm) light at a rate of 0.5 J·m−2·s−1 as measured by Kettering model 65 radiometer (Cole-Palmer Instrument Co., Vernon Hill, IL). After irradiation, fresh serum-free medium was added to cell culture and incubation continued for desired periods. Pfeifer G.P. Technologies for Detection of DNA Damage and Mutations. Plenum Press, New York1996: 199-210Crossref Google Scholar, 32.Tornaletti S. Pfeifer G.P. Science. 1994; 263: 1436-1438Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar). DNA, specifically cleaved at CPDs, was used to create blunt end DNA fragment by extension of primer specific to p53 with DNA sequenase 2.0. Blunt-ended DNA was then ligated to a double-strand linker and followed by amplification with the longer oligonucleotide of the linker and a second nested p53-specific primer. After 20–21 cycles of polymerase chain reaction, DNA fragments were size-fractionated on an 8% urea-polyacrylamide sequencing gel, electroblotted onto a nylon filter, and hybridized to a single-stranded p53-specific 32P-labeled probe generated by polymerase chain reaction using a third p53-specific primer. The filter was used to expose a PhosphorImager screen and the individual band intensities quantitated upon imaging and processing by Imagequant software (Molecular Dynamics). The filters were also used to expose Kodak X-Omat film for autoradiography and documentation by image scanning. LMPCR analysis of each sample was carried out in duplicate, and results described are from at least three independent experiments. Loss or disruption of normal p53 function generally results in decreased efficiency of repair of CPDs of non-transcribed DNA strand. To compare repair of CPDs in p53-WT containing normal human fibroblasts, p53-Mut, and p53-Null LFS fibroblasts, formation and removal of CPDs induced by UV at a dose of 20 J·m−2 were mapped by LMPCR, in both strands of exon 8 of p53 from genomic DNA.
